cryptohome/fake_platform/fake_mount_mapp.message: if there's nothing to unmount, this should return false.
Changed.

Just FYI: there's a (weird-ish) pattern we use for mounting a subtree as shared (so that mount/unmount events are propagated to peer mount groups): this involves doing a bind mount of a directory on to itself with MS_SHARED (and then the actual bind-mount/device is mounted on the directory). So, once you start moving mount-helper to use this, it will have some source==target bind mounts to deal with.

chrome/browser/metrics/process_memory_me.message: Why is it in fast_malloc and not malloc()?

With kPercentMetricRange we can no longer say that |kCustom| metric size is "in bytes". This is confusing at least. :(

Can we remove the percent metric from the memory dump? The various ways to analyze memory dumps can easily reconstruct the percentages from the "wasted". If we want to record percentage as a histogram, let's do it manually using UMA_HISTOGRAM_PERCENTAGE, it uses  UmaHistogramExactLinear() - behaves slightly differently than UmaHistogramCustomCounts(). It seems that to avoid undesired clipping we would need at least 102 buckets - but sorry, I did not prove that formally ;)

The EmitProcessUma() in this file is using base::UmaHistogramCustomCounts(... buckets=100) - so an accidental overflow would clip to 100% - we should rather make it a separate bucket. 

I just discovered some bonus material: http://crbug.com/1121318. About a year ago it was found that the number of buckets UmaHistogramPercentage() was incorrect (i.e different from UMA_HISTOGRAM_PERCENTAGE). Apparently it demonstrates that the histogram code is not easy to read :)

chromeos-base/languagepacks/handwriting/.message:
This needs to follow the naming pattern:
```
When uploading a new artifact to the mirror, make sure it has a unique name. This is usually accomplished using the basename form <project>-<version> or <project>-<some unique word>-<version>.
```

Hi Jae,
We need 5 files for each DLC. What's the best way to do that?
From what you told me it seems that it's preferable to do something like:
[
distfiles/languagepacks/handwriting_es_20210927_compact.fst.local
distfiles/languagepacks/handwriting_es_20210927_latin_indy.tflite
etc
]
This has an appropriate folder, project name, version and then filename.
It's a fairly long filename. Would you suggest something different?

Summarizing our offline conversation here:

With the above convention we will need to rename the files before they get packaged. We need to preserve the names because the Handwriting Engine expects specific filenames. So we can't change the names with ${PV}.

The next problem is whether this can be easily automated without using too much domain-specific knowledge. According to Jae:
"It is very generic. You will need to upload the files with certain naming to GS. And then uprev to the correct version. That’s actually how I setup the entire lacros ebuild. And it’s going pretty well. See chromes-lacros."

I would like to go through the option of using a single archive again.
Jae, for us it would be much simpler if we could put all 5 files into a single archive .xz and upload it to the gsmirror.
I know you mentioned that the problem is double compression/extraction.
Can you explain here what the drawbacks are and why we should not use that approach?
Thanks.

I suggest something like:
```
"gs://chromeos-localmirror/distfiles/languagepacks_handwriting_es-<FILENAME>-${PV}"
```

Where <FILENAME> is all the different files you'll be uploading.
This should keep the files unique + versioned correctly.

We reached a consensus offline.
All the files for the DLC can be compressed into a single tar.xz archive. (my bad for not understanding what the issue was).
We then package the raw files into the DLC in the ebuild.

Is it correct that there would be as many EventRewriters as the number of mapped keyboard combinations, etc.? If so, I see some downsides of the approach:

-  I'm not sure EventRewriter code takes account of having that many EventRewriters and there might be performance implications.
- If touch-to-touch mapping is possible (or added later), how an EventRewriter in a later stage tells it's already a rewritten event?

Given that, I'd prefer not to inherit EventRewriter here and instead have a single EventRewriter installed to each window.

Because each action is related to specific keys, it's hard to control and manage everything in a single EventRewriter. Even for a single EventRewriter, it needs to check each key which needs a lot of "if", so I don't think there is difference to check each Action/EventRewriter.

For distinguishing original touch from simulated touch in touch-touch mapping, there is SendEventFinally() which I think once it receives event, I can just call SendEventFinally() if the event is simulated to touch event, so it will not go through other EventRewriters.

And EventRewriters will be installed on root window. Only the EventRewriters associated with the focused window will be installed, which is implemented in next CL.

An anonymous namespace like this in a header is unexpected. From looking at constexpr char k* [] definitions in headers in the existing codebase, the ones I've seen all use named namespaces.

Anonymous namespace usage in a .cc file is common but is unusual in a .h file. In this code base, the headers I've found that define constants used a named (not anonymous namespace.) So this line would be something like "namespace InputOverlay {" (or whatever name you choose) and the matching comment closing the namespace would need to be updated as well. If the code that used the constants wasn't also in the same namespace, it would have to be updated to qualify the usage with InputOverlay:: or with a using directive.

I agree that we do not use anonymous namespace in header files. If we need to define variables in a header, the variables are intended to be used by the other files. It's a rare case where we need a distinct symbol for each translation unit.

In this case, please move the variables which are not used outside of input_overlay_resources_util.cc into the .cc file.
For the other variables, please put them in the specific namespace as Brad suggested. (maybe arc::input_overlay?)

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
Hey Adam,

Thanks for sending. I'm mostly OOO this week, so if you'd like to find another //net reviewer, that would be better. I've spent a fair bit of time on this CL, and trying to figure it out, but to be honest, I don't feel it's very clear to me how your changes here fit into the goal, and I haven't been able to convince myself this code is safe. I think this is probably a block on my side, but it feels like this code is increasing in complexity, rather than decreasing, and I'm not able to work out a clear API contract trying to be observed here.

That may make it easier to work with someone who can interactively work through this, and figure out if there are opportunities for simplification and strong/clear contracts. We've had enough (negative) experiences with ScopedFoo destruction order events that it feels that actively supporting them is probably something we should consider a non-goal, but I'm probably not seeing an important part of the problem, and so it could just be me here.
I think it's beneficial to make this more robust, even if it currently only fails in an unsupported configuration. What do you think?
Thanks for taking the time to look at this. I will have a go at fixing the tests that use ScopedPortException with incorrect nesting. Unfortunately they only run on ChromeOS.

net/base/port_util.cc.message: This feels dangerous to take thread-safe code and make it thread-hostile, and it's not clear why this change is good?

The existing code is not thread-safe. If any caller wants to use any of the functions in port_util.h from multiple threads, they have to insert the necessary memory barriers themselves, and make sure all the other callers in the same process respect those memory barriers. It's such a minefield that I'm seriously considering adding mutexes inside this file.

That structure is weird, with the request as both the key and the value. I am curious, if heterogeneous lookups should work (go/totw/144). It is like using overloaded comparators/hash, allowing multiple comparators/hash, one for raw pointer and one for unique_ptr.

Also, if you do not mind giving up O(1) lookups, we can store it in a vector, and use a custom comparator with find_if. That is something I am sure should work, since there is no key/hash function to be defined for both unique_ptr and raw pointer.
we need this for pending_tailored_security_requests_ when accessing the request. if there's a better way to do this, please let me know!

> we need this for pending_tailored_security_requests_ when accessing the request. if there's a better way to do this, please let me know!

You can still return a unique_ptr and add to pending_tailored_security_requests by getting the raw pointer with unique_ptr::get(). Download protection does that here: https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:chrome/browser/safe_browsing/download_protection/download_protection_service.cc;drc=757e4f41b5860ade0252886b5047d896dcac4fe8;l=226. /PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
I think this is the right thing to do, but can you explain the factory flow? When does the factory image get flashed and when does the release image get flashed? Is the FPMCU firmware pre-flashed?

Mainly, I want to make sure that the release FPMCU firmware is flashed when the factory is running the factory fingerprint sensor tests, which I think happens as part of the factory image: https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromiumos/platform/ec/+/HEAD/docs/fingerprint/fingerprint-factory-requirements.md#factory-tests.

> Is the FPMCU firmware pre-flashed?
AFAIK, the FPMCU usually are not pre-flashed with the target firmware so we have to flash them in the factory flow.

> When does the factory image get flashed and when does the release image get flashed?
Both images get pre-flashed or get flashed by netboot or get flashed by USB install shim. The ODM can choose the image method. This slides [1] briefly introduce different image methods.

> Can you explain the factory flow?

I will list the fpmcu related part.

assemble the device -> flash image if it's not pre-flashed in the SSD -> boot to factory image -> boot-update-firmware skips Fpmcu firmware update since it's factory mode -> mount the release partition and extract the release firmware -> use flash_fp_mcu to flash it -> test fingerprint functionality using ectool -> probe the fpmcu and record the info in HWID -> verify fpmcu firmware keys -> initialize fpmcu entropy -> Wipe the stateful partition and factory image -> cutoff battery -> device is ready

For early phase (prePVT), some steps may be waived.

[1]: https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1S1wUMU7XWcyWQ2OylqGpcx3QC0LmL5837bAekV1QNQ0/edit#slide=id.g184af8f66_059

ResetForFollowRedirect would take following arguments.

- url_loader_modified_headers_

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
This is the intended behavior and acceptable in this case because the container doesn't use the (address, address) comparison.

It's implemented this way for efficiency purposes -- heterogeneous lookup on addresses in the std::set<> is a O(log(n)) operation because it takes advantage of underlying balanced tree representation.

Use of std::upper_bound() on the std::set<> on the other hand is O(n). std::set<> only provides a LegacyBidirectionalIterator, not a LegacyRandomAccessIterator, so the bisection step is O(n).
Ah, sorry about that. A previous version of this code used std::upper_bound() on the set so I think I was primed to see that rather than std::set<>::upper_bound(). :)

author.name: Joe Mason
author.status: OOO on the 2nd, 4th and 5th Friday of each month

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
It makes me nervous to violate the Compare semantics, even if the usage here seems ok. I think depending on find() not using the invalid comparisons is assuming too much about the implementation.

Note this uses std::set<>::upper_bound, not std::upper_bound, which should have the same efficiency as std::set<>::find. https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/container/set/upper_bound lists it as "logarithmic complexity".

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: Thanks for tackling this!

Isn't this effectively still templating on the container type?

base/profiler/module_cache.cc.message:
Well, Range has a more constrained interface than a container (basically just a begin and end iterator) so there's less risk of people calling functions with non-obvious semantics when they're passed an unexpected container type.

But since the templated function is causing so much confusion here, I can duplicate the code for each type. That makes the function signatures simpler, too, although it does mean anyone who adds validation steps needs to remember to update both functions.

author.status: OOO on the 2nd, 4th and 5th Friday of each month

base/profiler/module_cache.h.message:
The Comparator semantic requires that "if comp(a,b)==true and comp(b,c)==true then comp(a,c)==true", for all a,b,c. So if a=address1, b=m1, c=address2, we need to have a defined comparator for comp(address1, address2).

It's not critical since the compiler will complain about the missing operator if it becomes necessary, but I think it's better to fully implement the Compare semantic.

Ack. Practically speaking it seems very unlikely that an STL set<> implementation would ever need the (address, address) comparison, since no member function ever takes more than one of those and the container type is not templated on the type so it can't be stored on the object without something like std::any.

Implementing for consistency is fine though.

base/profiler/module_cache_unittest.cc.message: We should never see a module of length 0 in practice. Let's DCHECK this in the code rather than supporting it as a valid case.

> I haven't checked all platforms, but on posix at least a module with no executable segment will have length 0:
> 
> https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:base/profiler/module_cache_posix.cc;l=57;drc=7dd58adeb690920a7474b4f7c5d71d23b15d4698

Good point. I was thinking that the module itself can't be of size 0 simply because it at least contains an ELF or Mach-O header. Arguably it would be better for the size computation code to match this and default to sizeof(Elf32_Ehdr) / sizeof(Elf64_Ehdr) / sizeof(MachHeaderType) rather than 0 if there's no text section. That's more sensible to reason about.

But that seems beyond the scope of this CL. Your suggestion to return nullptr from CreateModuleForAddress SGTM.

author.name: Joe Mason
author.status: OOO on the 2nd, 4th and 5th Friday of each month

base/profiler/module_cache_unittest.cc.message:
I haven't checked all platforms, but on posix at least a module with no executable segment will have length 0:

https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:base/profiler/module_cache_posix.cc;l=57;drc=7dd58adeb690920a7474b4f7c5d71d23b15d4698

(I think there's still no way to have a second module at the same address, because the non-executable segments take up some space that no other module can occupy.)

Is the idea that CreateModuleForAddress is guaranteed to never be called outside an executable segment? That seems hard to guarantee - that code looks like it has a lot of corner cases. More correct to say "a module whose executable segment couldn't be located will have length 0".

I think I should return nullptr from CreateModuleForAddress instead of DCHECK'ing if length is 0. WDYT?

components/autofill_assistant/browser/tr.message: JFYI, the precursor CL has been reverted the last week, but I can't get enough information to reland the CL.

Sorry, I indeed intended to write "DidFinishNavigation / PrimaryPageChanged".

The not-covered cases are the cases where the user didn't navigate to a new page — e.g. navigations which end up being downloads, return HTTP 204 code or just are cancelled before committing.

Both of the cases you mention are the cases when the user navigates to a new page, so using PrimaryPageChanged should be safe.

I think this could indeed be moved, to line ~353 (I assume you meant PrimaryPageChanged?), but it would be good for me to understand first which cases would not be covered by the move. 

To give some context, our UI has a not-now button, which hides the UI until the next time our trigger conditions are satisfied. This should typically be the case when the user (a) refreshes the page, or (b) navigates back and then forth again. As long as PrimaryPageChanged is notified in both of those cases, moving this should be safe.
Done with moving this to PrimaryPageChanged as suggested.
ack, sg. Thanks for the context! Feel free to move this as suggested.
Question to the owners: the page here can be restored from bfcache. Are we okay with running the trigger script for it for the second time?

I'm not sure I understood that, could you clarify what the bfcache is? If you're saying that a PrimaryPageChanged notification might just be a restore-from-cache event, that's fine (and the highlighted line should stay).

Basically, this does not run the trigger script again, it just forces a check of the trigger conditions. We expect events like reloading a page, and others, to trigger this notification (if they don't, our experience can be broken in some cases).
Ack, thanks for clarifying! Yes, in that case, it makes sense to keep this the way it is. Going back or forward to the trigger site should indeed re-run the trigger conditions.
BFCache is back/forward cache, which stores the pages after the user has navigated away from them for the purpose of restoring them from the cache later (instead of loading them from scratch).

content/browser/renderer_host/render_fra.message:
Could we check that the lifecycle_state here isn't kSpeculative or kCommitPending? 
The reason is that kSpeculative / kCommitPending RFHs haven't committed a navigation, so this function will always return false (which probably isn't something that the user has anticipated).

media/gpu/v4l2/v4l2_video_decoder.cc.message:
base::Unretained(this) does seem safe, but base::Unretained(backend_.get()) is less clear because |backend_| can get destroyed in some places within V4L2VideoDecoder, so I think that one needs more justification.

I don't think the justification could be the same as the one for base::ScopedClosureRunner done_caller before this CL because in that case, the call to OnChangeResolutionDone() would have happened inside the same method before |backend_| could possibly be modified.

Hmm you're right. We cannot guarantee |backend_| is still alive when calling |continue_change_resolution_cb_|.
Let me wrap OnChangeResolutionDone() and add the null check.
Should this happen in V4L2VideoDecoder::Initialize() as well when doing a re-initialization?
Should we check |backend_|? I'm not quite sure if we can get here with a null |backend_|. I don't believe so.

I found we should move this part below (state_ == State::kInitialized) statement, because |backend_| is lazily created when the first input buffer arrives.
Let me add one more check for backend_ as well.
We are about to release the old backend in V4L2VideoDecoder::Initialize(), so I don't think we need to call OnChangeResolutionDone() before releasing it.

I wonder if this can even happen (before or after this CL):

For one thing, when VDPipeline::Reset() is called, we set need_apply_new_resolution = false so we shouldn't call V4L2VideoDecoder::ApplyResolutionChange(). Also, V4L2VD::Reset() resets continue_change_resolution_cb_.

Maybe leave this as-is, but add a TODO to revisit it.
nit: Add a comment saying that we don't need to call SetState(State::kError) because ContinueChangeResolution() should have already done so if there was no |backend_|.

media/gpu/v4l2/v4l2_video_decoder_backen.message: Hmm, can you refresh my memory? Why does this need to be handled differently than in the Stateless backend?

VaapiVD and stateless use AcceleratedVideoDecoder (AVD) to parse the header.
We reset or re-initialize the AVD when VD::Reset() is called.
So AVD will trigger the resolution change after reset.
However, the stateful backend won't trigger the resolution change event after reset.
Therefore we need explicitly trigger the resolution change at the stateful backend.
I add the logic at the next CL.
https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/3132321/7/media/gpu/v4l2/v4l2_video_decoder_backend_stateful.cc#634

Three things:

2. I feel we should add a notification type or category instead of adding InteractionBehavior. That is not aligned with its original design intention.
3. Like above comment, incoming call should have answer and hang up actions. Why only one action_id is added?
